Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Three-wave mixing techniques to study and utilize nuclear quadrupole coupling effects in chiral molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many molecules in nature, particularly biological molecules, exhibit a handedness in their geometric structure. This is to say two molecules can have the same number and kinds of atoms and geometric arrangement, but they are mirror images of each other, as are one's left and right hands. This "handedness" in chemistry is referred to as "chirality." In chemical measurements, distinguishing between the "hands"- known as enantiomers- and quantifying the amounts of each can be a difficult technological challenge. This difficulty can limit our ability to synthesize and separate a given enantiomer. In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanism (CSDM-A) and Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Programs of the Chemistry Division, Professor Garry Grubbs II of the Missouri University of Science and Technology is using advanced microwave spectroscopy techniques to determine the type and concentration of enantiomers present in a sample. Microwave spectroscopy provides information about molecular structure based on how fast they can be made to rotate by the microwave radiation. Professor Grubbs hypothesizes that "handedness" of a molecule can be determined if that molecule contains a very heavy atom like bromine or iodine. The nuclei of these heavy atoms contain arrangements of electrical charge that can make the rotations of the overall molecule reveal more about its structure in a microwave experiment than it would otherwise. If Professor Grubbs' hypothesis is correct, there may be new paths toward faster and more accurate synthesis and monitoring of chiral systems, which is particularly important to pharmaceutical research. The project is also training graduate students in currently unexplored areas of physical chemistry using state-of-the-art instrument design as well as new quantum theory development.

This project focuses on utilizing the recent discovery of microwave three-wave mixing in chiral systems on nuclear electric quadrupole coupling interactions. These experiments are designed to establish, for the first time, experimental data and theoretical understanding for nuclear spin-based methodologies for identifying and quantifying enantiomeric species in mixtures. Microwave three-wave mixing involves utilizing rotational transitions involving excitation along two molecular axes while detecting along the third axis, creating closed-loop transition energy pathways very similar to a three-level maser system. Electric dipole-forbidden, quadrupole-facilitated transitions occur when off-diagonal nuclear electric quadrupole interactions are on the order of the molecular rotation constants and follow the same closed-loop pathway. These are then leveraged using microwave three-wave mixing because of the technique's sensitivity to phase rather than energy of traditional microwave spectroscopy, allowing for the determination of the off-diagonal sign in a singular experiment for the first time as well as insight into the enantiomer in question. Isotopic substitution spectra analysis are then used to validate the veracity of the experimental results. In addition to the technological and educational impacts, this research may expand the reach of, and molecular information offered from, microwave spectroscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in many positive outcomes. 10 products are directly related to this work. This includes 5 accepted peer-review publications, 1 publication under revision, and 4 conference presentations.

The original goal for this project was to find new ways to qualify and quantify chiral species in mixtures by employing the recently discovered microwave three-wave mixing spectroscopy technique on electric dipole-forbidden, nuclear quadrupole coupling allowed transitions. These transitions are known to be brought about by a similar quantum mechanical pathway as that which generates a known out-of-phase time-domain signal response in chiral molecules. This was to be accomplished by first isolating molecules and pathways to be tested using traditional broadband microwave techniques, build a microwave three-wave mixing experiment in order to perform these tests, and determine if this was a viable route to identifying chiral species. The PI and his team were able to successfully isolate, measure, and assign a potential molecule for study with the chiral molecule 2-bromo-1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane with the possible transition pathways mentioned in the publication. A microwave three-wave mixing spectrometer was also successfully constructed as a result of this project.

In the process of measuring broadband spectra and building the three-wave mixing experiment, however, a new discovery was made which could potentially change the way broadband microwave spectroscopy is performed. This was that molecular signal is generated in all directions in the broadband microwave experiment, providing an avenue to increase sensitivity in the technique without having to increase sample consumption or power. This discovery provided the basis for a NSF Major Research Instrumentation project to further demonstrate, validate, and construct such an instrument. It is expected that these potential sensitivity increases will find their way into a new generation of broadband microwave spectrometer designs.

Furthermore, the knowledge gained during the building of the microwave three-wave mixing experiment also paved the way to enhance the understanding and teaching of rotational spectroscopy at the undergraduate level. This culminated in a lower-cost Balle-Flygare instrument and physical chemistry teaching lab. Given the scarcity of experimental examples and resources in the area of pure rotational spectroscopy, this lab was designed to help students utilize instrumentation common to the field while also understanding and interpreting experimental measurements on a known astrophysically relevant molecule, benzonitrile. Framing the experiment in this way both showed students what applications existed for rotational spectroscopy and made connections to their lectures on the subject from their quantum chemistry coursework.

Beyond the scientific and pedagogical outcomes of this project, one important outcome was the development and training of students. Three graduate students, two of which are women, and one undergraduate worked on this project directly. One of the graduate students received his PhD in 2019 and now works in industry in spectrometer applications. The undergraduate received his Bachelor's of Science from Missouri S&T in the spring of 2020 and is continuing his studies in pursuit of a PhD with PI Grubbs. All students involved in the project have extended their scientific networks with other students and researchers in the molecular spectroscopy community by attending and giving oral presentations at the International Symposium on Molecular Spectroscopy in Illinois.
